author: holiman
content: <@!301186049323958275> I don't think you need a sentinel, if you add one item to the list. And if you did, sending in `32`bytes of `ff` seems  wasteful, since it isn't compressed in the RLP.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!211091239112671234> I agree.  Settled on a much slimmer and easier to manage solution in EIP-2718

author: pipermerriam

content: - <@!301186049323958275> and/or myself can cover the loose plan that is forming via Meta-Transaction + UNGAS to get to a place where we have freedom of movement to reprice operations to account for witness size via gas.

author: pipermerriam
content: - I would like to talk about "Snap" sync in the context of binary tries and whether anyone has intuition on whether 1) it would still be viable under a binary trie and 2) if so, maybe we can table MGR concept and start moving towards actual binary trie spec if we thing Snap can serve as a viable sync protocol under a binary trie

author: holiman
content: Sorry, had to go. Re snap -- it has now moved from "proof of concept" into actually doing a robust, concurrency-enabled protocol implementation, with all bells and whistles + testcases surrounding cornercases and malicious peers. It doesn't matter what format (binary or hexary)  the backing trie has, but the ability to "heal" a non-complete trie with the use of fast-sync (getNodeData)  is an important final step

author: pipermerriam
content:
<@!211091239112671234> thanks for bringing up ACD.  It reminds me personally that I should re-prioritize that call.  I'm interested in a broader conversation about how that call can be re-invented so that it suffers less from this slow "attrition" or tragedy-of-the-commons problem that I personally experienced where the call felt a little bit like "theatre" where I was on-stage with the implicit ask to make decisions in a public setting where it didn't feel entirely safe to have a candid discourse. T

To state that in a different way, the call seems to try and serve two different purposes.  1) a medium through which we can make decisions about the core protocol 2) a public "town-hall" ish where the broader community can both see how the decisions are being made as well as have their voice heard.

The problem I see is that the "town-hall" element exists to the detriment of the decision making since I personally feel like anytime I speak up in that call I'm on stage for the world to see and thus, it isn't a safe place to test out ideas, debate things, etc.  I don't know how best to address that problem, but I think if we can address it then we can potentially get broader participation on the call and in theory more easily make better decisions.

author: pipermerriam
content: Recording of today's call available.  DM me if you'd like the link
